headline: Bread Machine Challah
description: This bread machine challah recipe is simple to make with basic pantry staples and bakes up 2 rich, tender, slightly sweet loaves with a pillowy crumb.
name: Bread Machine Challah

recipeInstructions.text: Place warm water, sugar, oil, eggs, honey, salt, flour, and yeast into a bread machine in the order listed, or follow the order recommended by the manufacturer if different. Select Dough cycle; press Start.
Remove dough from the machine after the cycle is done and place on a lightly floured board. Punch dough down and let rest for 5 minutes.

Divide dough in half, then divide each half into 3 equal pieces. Roll each piece into ropes, about 12- to 14-inches long. Braid 3 ropes into a loaf to form 2 loaves. Gently place loaves onto the prepared baking tray. Mist loaves with water and cover loosely with plastic wrap. Let rise in a warm, draft-free place until doubled in size, 1 to 1 1/2 hours.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
Make egg wash: Beat together egg and water in a small bowl until well combined.
Brush the top and sides of loaves with egg wash.
Bake in the preheated oven for about 20 to 25 minutes. If loaves begin to brown too soon, cover them loosely with aluminum foil.

review.reviewBody: Easy and turned out tasty! I added 1/2 cup more flour. I have learned to put the salt in first and make sure the yeast is in a small flour circle on top. Thank you for sharing this as it isn't hard for my arthritic hands to do.
Use 515 grams of flour. Then the bread is delicious. Also, I only had active dry yeast at home. I proofed it with 1 tsp of the sugar and 1/4 cup of the water for the recipe. Worked out fine.
This was the EASIEST, prettiest bread I've ever made. And tasty!!
Though it's a long process, the directions were clear and the challah came out great!
This recipe is almost perfect. Next time I will add another tsp. of sugar. I may try making it with 3 eggs (plus the egg for the egg wash , making you need 4 eggs total for this recipe.
Just made it! Wow this is a great recipe. One loaf is half gone and it's been 10 minutes! I read the reviews and added an extra 1/2 cup of flour. Otherwise just followed recipe exactly. Great recipe.

Even though the dough its loose. it came out so puffy and taste amazingly well. Everyone complement it on my shabbat table. I will keep it making in mine machine. Observation I cooked inside my machine so I just separate the dough with a spatula not to ruin the teflon. I suggest if you want braid it add 1/2 cup flour extra to the recipe or little more until you see a manageable dough. But really the taste of this challah it was superior.
Followed instructions. Didn‚Äôt rise had to through out. What a waste of ingredients üëéüèΩ
My challah in my bread machine came out so fluffy and yummy! I‚Äôll use this recipe again and again!

Took the advice given in some of the reviews abs added a little extra flour. I also adjusted the recipe to make it more diabetic friendly. Used whole grain bread flour and reduced the sugar. Turned out amazing. Will be making this again.

So easy to make. I was able to put it in the bread machine while working at home, and then finish after work in time for dinner. No problems such as those mentioned in other reviews. Also...I'm at high altitude, and it worked great! Will definitely repeat!

The best challah recipe and I have experimented with a few!
 The whole family loved it and it was beautiful the next morning covered with homemade blackberry jam!

I followed the directions exactly, the bread was so sticky after it came out of the bread maker that it was impossible to do anything with. Thanks a lot for all the waste of time, ingredients, and effort. I can‚Äôt imagine how on earth this has such good ratings
Absolutely fabulous bread. I would give 10 stars if I could. It stays fresh for days.The only changes I made are using butter instead of oil and cutting sugar, but it's my personal preference.
Came out excellent! Added 1/2 C more flour as others suggested
Followed the directions and it came out beautifully.

First of all, it was easy to make in the bread machine. Yes, I did add the extra 1/2 cup of flour as recommended. The dough was perfect. The honey gives it a sweet taste. It made two large loaves. Next time I will divide into three loaves since I had to cut the loaves in half for storage. One thing, I have a convection oven so I only baked it for 15 minutes but that was too long. Any longer and it would have burned the crust. So watch it carefully. My loaves came out dark brown but still moist. Otherwise it's a quick and easy way to prepare the tasty bread all year long. I bet this would be terrific for french toast.

Like others, I found that 4 cups of flour wasn't enough. The dough was like cake batter. Wound up adding almost a full cup of additional flour before the final rise. Adding the flour then, without additional kneading, adversely affected both the taste and texture of the challah. Next time, I will start out with closer to 5 cups of flour, and see if that improves things.

Nope, nope, nope. 
I did what others had said and added 1/2c of flour from the beginning. Not only did this not become dough, I could POUR it like cake batter. When the machine was done kneading, I added more flour (I didn‚Äôt measure but it was a LOT) until it was more of a dough consistency and mixed it again. It was still sticky enough that I had to keep adding flour on my rolling surface because it was like glue. Eventually I got to something that could be braided but I‚Äôm so far from the recipe that I‚Äôd be lying if I reviewed this as anything more than a complete failure.

I don't usually write a review... But in this instance its a must. This recipe came out perfectly. I used our machines measuring cup and followed this recipe exactly. Got soft workable dough after the dough circle. Kneaded slightly then let a rest. I knotted the dough rested it again for close to 2 hours in a warm spot then baked. Perfect Challah followed.
Great recipe! I, like others who commented, added about a 3/4 cup of flour extra in order to make the dough not so sticky. Otherwise it's perfect!
It was delicious and soft. I had run out of eggs so brushed it with softened butter and sprinkled some coarse salt on top it was awesome. Texture was perfect.
So good, no changes!
Amazing! Add ‚Äúkruszonka‚Äù on top, it‚Äôs crunchy and sweet.
Will not be making this again.

It‚Äôs the second time I‚Äôve made it. My bread machine didn‚Äôt come with a challah recipe, so I used this one without any idea the order of ingredients. I put the dry ingredients in first then the wet. I added an extra 1/2 c flour the first time, but the dough flattened just before baking (when I brushed it with egg), so the second time I added an extra 1 c flour and an extra tsp of yeast. Otherwise everything else was the same. The density & rising was perfect the second time (even after brushing with egg). The taste remained delicious. Thank you.
This is a great recipe!! Our loaves of Challah were delicious.
added an additional half cup of flour as suggested by others
I used one cup whole wheat flour
Had to keep in oven much longer, maybe it's oven's fault.
Very easy to make. Dough is very silky. Felt good to the hands. Sublime!

Delicious! A great first, braided challah. We added 1/2 cup flour (it was all-purpose) as suggested by others, 580 grams in total on a kitchen scale. Also we used 1/4 cup (1/2 stick) butter, melted, and 1/4 cup oil. Making sure it wasn‚Äôt hotter than 110‚Äô before adding, to protect the yeast.

I made 1/2 the recipe (one loaf) and it came out wonderfully. A little dab of cream cheese and you have a great snack. I took off a star because I needed about 1/4 more flour on the dough, plus you have to be prepared that even with good kneading it might be a touch sticky. Put poppy seeds on top.
I make this recipe all the time. Go with Sam‚Äôs bread flour, you will thank me later. Love it!

Loved this recipe- but only with addition of extra flour. I also threw in a few threads of saffron for the colour and flavour. With the extra flour the bread had that Challah flavour and texture that I love.

This was fabulous! I used coconut oil and increased the flour to nearly 5 cups because it's been so humid here. I also made one large braid instead of two smaller ones and baked it for 40 minutes. Other than that, I used the recipe as written and was very pleased with the results!

Made this one time and followed the directions pretty closely. Only changes I made was using a stick of butter instead of vegetable oil and used less sugar but more honey and some dark agave sweetener. The taste of this first attempt at Challah bread was phenomenal, but the texture was weird. Unfortunately, I hadn't read the reviews before I got started to be warned about the sticky texture. I baked it anyway, although it was globular looking loaf as braiding it like regular Challah seemed impossible.

Lesson learned. Second attempt I once again replaced vegetable oil with butter and cut down on white sugar and added more honey, but no agave nectar since I'm out. I also added about 1/2 cup extra flour and an extra half pack of yeast. I just took it out of the bread machine and must say the texture now is ON POINT! I easily braided it this time and this will probably make a beautiful loaf! I'm letting it rise now and haven't baked it and tasted it, but since the ingredients are pretty much the same I think it will still taste awesome, the half cup flour shouldn't change the taste much (I hope). I just wanted to write this review so I could remember how I got the good texture before I forget it.
Tip: Make 2, 1 pound loaves, opposed too rolling making 1 large, make 2 small with the recipe for 1

Loved it! mixed AP flour with High Gluten flour to achieve the bread flour results. 
Also added about 3/4 cups extra flour. 
Love my usual recipe, but it is a tad small, this is just a little larger.
Love this recipe!

Something went horribly wrong with this recipe. I followed the ingredients and instructions to the letter. The dough was so soft it was like cookie dough. I could not form the loaves and it never did rise. This is the first time of cooking for 60 years that I threw away the dough.
I really liked the taste of this bread and I will definitely make it again
Great recipe and so easy to make. Delicious out of the oven but also thawed after freezing.
Absolutely amazing recipe! I can't keep it in the house lol all of my boys love it! I've made it twice and will keep this forever. Easy and it makes 2 big loaves

I make this all the time I premeasure most of the ingredients and put into appropriate containers plastic bags. When I want to make it all I have to do is grab the pre measured ingredients and into the bread maker they go. 
My family loves this recipie and I make it all the time not just for Shabbat

Fairly simple. I read other reviews which said to add more flour, and I wish I hadn't. I ended up only adding 1/4 cup extra, but had a tough time "rolling" the dough into the braid pieces. I did end up with two loaves and froze one before the rising stage.

Very easy Challah recipe. Made it 3 times. It was a little sticky twice, but I added about a tablespoon of flour to the finished dough right after it came out of the bread pan and it was easy to work with. Made braided loaves and rolls and one loaf in a bread pan. Added poppy seeds to the top of the last loaf. Will use this again. Next one with Sesame seeds. Thanks for the great recipe.
Loved this recipe! Turned out perfect on the first try!!
I followed the recipe exactly and the bread turned out perfectly! It was moist and flavourful. I would recommend this recipe to anyone interested in making Challah bread for the holidays.
Fabulous. It didn't rise as much as I thought before baking, but made up for it in the oven.

I have reviewed this bread before, it's one of our favourites. I did say that I made no changes, however, I've read so many reviews complaining about the dough being too sticky. As I'm quite experienced with my machine now, I never put ingredients in and walk away. It's always a good idea to stick around until the dough is just about mixed, but the machine is still kneading. Check the dough to judge if you need to add flour or water at this stage and scrape away any flour from the sides that the machine hasn't managed to include. Do this, and you should have a perfect dough every time. Bear in mind that the dough for challah is slightly more sticky.

Got rave reviews from my housemates on this one. The first time I didn't grease the tray properly but it was still delicious. I did two triple braids and stacked them, which worked fine. The second time it was very humid so the dough came out too sticky. I over floured it trying to get the rolls to stay intact while doing a single 6-braid (which was not worth the hassle), and then over-baked it trying to get the top to brown more. It still came out well though despite my missteps.

This was really great, nice flavor and texture! I changed the water to milk and used 1 cup of white whole wheat and 3 cups of bread flour. The salt in this recipe is far too much. I reduced it to 2 tsp and still will reduce it more next time. Will make again with above changes. Had a bit of a sticky dough, but just used a little flour on the board and hands to remedy.

I attempted to make this in my Zojirushi. It came out a crumbly mess that I couldn't even hand knead into usable dough. I noticed that all the reviews seem to say that the dough is too sticky or wet, I can't see how that is at all possible. I did the recipe exactly as written.

Very tasty and it just disappeared. I did several of the Challah
recipes with my bread machine. I brought it to our lenten
soup supper. This one was the best of all. I also didn't like
the really sticky dough. I added more flour, just didn't measure it. Thank you to the one's that said add 1/2 a cup. I had bought Red Star Bread Machine Yeast and finally tried, since my other yeast was almost gone. I love it. I like making the two breads from this recipe.
Excellent! I added an egg and it was the best challah i have ever made!

Best challah recipe ever! Finished challah has great elasticity and is not too sweet. I used ordinary, all purpose, unbleached flour and also needed to add 1/2 cup more than recipe calls for. I used 3 tsp of yeast in all. Dough will rise substantially while in the oven. It turned out perfectly. Note: dough has to be a bit sticky in order to roll nice ropes for braiding. Use flour sparingly for rolling and braiding. Enjoy! We sure did!

I have made this recipe a lot, so some advice , the amount of flour may varied from 4 cup to 5, that depends in some thing like the temparature, the humidity , the size of the eggs the tips of honey you use.
This recipe consistently turns out well.
Excellent. We make this all the time and substitute with 1.5 cups of whole wheat flower. Yummy!
I needed almost one more cup of flour. Flavor is nice which is why I gave it three stars. The current ratio produces a dough that is much too sticky to work with.

I baked two loaves last night and had one of them for breakfast this morning. We've been buying challah in London for a few years and mine was the best . Simply Delicious.
I agree with the comments about the dough being sticky which makes it difficult to plait. Next time I 'll add that extra 1/2 cup of flour which should improve consistency.

This challah tastes great, but the recipe does take some finessing. I have to add between .5 to 1 cup extra flour or else the dough is far too wet when it comes out of the bread machine. I often substitute maple syrup for honey since I don't have honey on hand, and that's it for modifications. Good challah.
Love this recipe! I used some whole wheat flour cut some sugar, and they still turned out to be awesome!

I tried this recipe using 2 cups bread flour, and 2 1/2 cups white wheat flour and it turned out perfect! My 4 kids almost ate the entire first loaf with their dinner tonight. With the remaining loaf, I sliced and am preparing a French Toast Casserole in the a.m. I've never made challah before, and never even tasted it so I'm not sure what to compare it to, but regardless, it's a wonderful bread. Thanks for sharing!

This was a hit at our family christmas party! So glad I made two batches. Adding 1/2 cup extra flour made a perfect doughball and braided easily. The family wants me to make it again before next christmas!

I found the same as many previous users, this dough came out uber sticky and mine actually didn't rise much either. Since I already had the dough made, I went ahead and baked it. It tastes decent, although I found it a little too salty. I think I will try again with the adjustments of adding more flour and using a little less salt. Do people think additional yeast would help this recipe as well?

I had originally come to find a recipe for French bread but when I saw this gorgeous challah..I HAD to make it. Hubs had never had challah before and I hadn't had it in ages. It was INCREDIBLE. I mean, baker's quality. I used APF since I never keep bread flour in the house and I didn't use honey as I was all out and had no problem working with the dough whatsoever. Hubs wanted to eat the whole loaf in one sitting!!! Kids loved it too. I'm not sure if the lack of honey/use of APF changed the texture or anything but I had no sticky issues at all so maybe that'll help someone!

With a lot of tweaking, this recipe turns out well. I live in the Deep South, where the humidity changes everything in the kitchen. By adding a little flour during the kneading process in the bread machine and during the braiding, I found the baked loaves to be as pretty as they should be. The baking sheet or pan needs to be greased for the challah to completely come off of it. I tried using the beaten whole egg for the glaze and found that it made the bread taste strongly of egg, which should never happen with challah. The solution: use egg white. I am grateful to have found this recipe, because I have carpal tunnel syndrome and need a machine to knead for me. Thanks to the person who shared it for making my family's Shabbat more enjoyable, with no need to run to a special bakery for bread, call ahead for it, and so forth!
Necessary to ad 1/2 cup of flour; the doubt is very sticky. But the result is very good.

Does anyone know how to convert from bread machine to non-bread machine?

Love this bread! BUT, I always need to add more flour since it ends up too sticky to work with.

Once I braid it, let it rise and then bake, the braids lose all their definition and it looks more like a loaf bread than a challah... any ideas????

Thanks!

Loved it !! It is a keeper. For my own family likes I substituted one stick of butter for the 1/2 cup vegetable oil because we love butter baked in bread. Based on previous reviews; I added in extra egg for 3 eggs total and added in 1/2 cup more flour for a total of 4 1/2 cups of bread flour.

Loved it !! It is a keeper. For my own family likes I substituted one stick of butter for the 1/2 cup vegetable oil because we love butter baked in bread. Based on previous reviews; I added in extra egg for 3 eggs total and added in 1/2 cup more flour for a total of 4 1/2 cups of bread flour.
Needed 5 cups of flour and 1 tablespoon of SAF Red yeast, but with those changes it rocked!

This is my favorite challah recipe - I use it weekly and get rave reviews. I only gave it 4 stars bc as it is written, it's not as good as I make it :). Add more honey, some extra flour (including 1/2 cup whole wheat flour instead of all white flour), and 2 TBSP of yeast (instead of teaspoons) for the perfect challah. Mine doesn't end up rising as much as other challah - and if I cook it perfectly (350 for 23 minutes or so), it comes out deliciously sticky and sweet. Pieces pull apart and guests keep coming back for more!

I have been making this for about 2 years. This is hands down the easiest and tastiest Challah. No one can get enough of it! I have made it exactly as written and it comes out great. However these days, I do not measure the honey so tend to put a little more in. I also add an extra 1/2 C of flour and 1/4 tsp yeast.

I agree with another lady that said the dough was so 'sticky'. I kept adding flour, more flour, etc. and ended up with 2 small loaves of rather heavy,dense breads.... not the two pleasing small loaves I was hoping for. I will not make this again.

This is my go to bread machine challah recipe that comes out every time. Haven‚Äôt made the recipe in about four years and forgot how sticky the dough gets. However, with a little bit of flour on the surface when rolling it out, it becomes easy to work with. I follow Maya‚Äôs video, https://youtu.be/22p3wIHLupc, to make 6 -strand braided challah and everyone enjoys the finished product!
Delicious!!! So soft and moist! I wish I could braid it tighter so that it looked prettier like the photo! Absolutely wonderful! My family loved it!

Can't believe I never reviewed this recipe...have been using for a couple of years. It is fantastic! I make just as written except usually use 4 1/2 cups of flour. I also sprinkle with sesame seeds or poppy seeds after the egg wash. This is an unbelievably great recipe, which my husband loves! Thank you SO much for this wonderful recipe...now if I could only braid the bread better!

I make this recipe every week now and I think it is outstanding. One point of disagreement with the reviewers here - yes the dough is sticky, but adding so much additional flour changes the texture away from the tender and light qualities of the original. I've found that if I am diligent about having floured hands and a floured board (but not too much flour!) the stickiness problem drops considerably. It also helps to divide the recipe into 3 loaves rather than 2, and to flour a pastry cutter to help transfer the loaves onto the baking stone. also, to get a super shiny glaze, egg wash once after braiding, and a second time after rising. enjoy!

Having read previous comments, I knew this recipe might come out wet and sticky. It was extremely wet and I added quite a bit of flour during initial cycle. However it really did not rise. I baked it in a bread pan. It did not bake well and the center was not done. I usually have good luck with other well rated recipes, but I was very disappointed in this one.

Outrageously good! I see no reason to ever use another bread recipe. Usually I find homemade bread bland and disappointing, but this is great and the texture was perfect. I know some people have mentioned consistency problems, but mine was perfect - flour is finicky. On a relatively dry, cold day, my dough was smooth and satiny and perfect, and I used all of the proportions listed in the recipe (maybe a bit more salt). Thank you so much - great recipe!
i love this recipe i have had to put a little more flour but it always comes out perfect and last week i made it into whole wheat bread :D
This is the recipe I use every week. I add vanilla (1-2 tsp).

I made this recipe exactly as directed, and THEN read the reviews...so I had a moment of panic when I thought for sure it wasn't going to turn out right. But, much to my delight, I had no problems. The dough was slightly sticky, but nothing a little flour on the hands couldn't fix. It was easy to work with, and it turned out wonderfully! We really enjoyed this bread, and I will be making it a lot. Also, if anyone is in need of a good laugh, I submitted a picture of my bread. The camera made it look yellow (which it is not in real life, it is a lovely brown), and my braiding skills leave much to be desired (as my daughter has been telling me since she could talk), but the bread is delicious and that is what matters :)
I also added the extra 3/4 cup of flour
I also added the extra 3/4 cup of flour
My family loves this bread and it comes out perfect every time. My kids love the sweetness. Definite keeper!
Good recipe!!!
I have made this recipe many times over the last 10+ years - it is absolutely fabulous!
Just made this for the first time. I've tried several bread machine challah recipes and this is the very best.

This recipe was actually perfect in the flour/water ratio. The dough should be slightly sticky/moist. And I got the right texture.

Remember it makes a huge, and I mean HUGE difference in different climates/humidity etc. I would err with the least and then check the dough mid cycle to see if you need more flour or water. 

Meanwhile, I did two braids from this recipe, and baked up great. Thanks,

Followed this recipe exactly except I added sesame seeds on top before baking and it turned out amazing! This was my first time making Challah, and only my second time eating it. My husband and I finish off the entire loaf because it was so good! I ended up braiding both halves and freezing one in a greased freezer bag. I can't wait to bake it up in a few weeks!
Too gooey. Did not work at all. Did it twice. Same result twice.

I spent today making this recipe and Bread Machine Challah I. I have to say I like Bread Machine Challah I much more. 

For this recipe, I did what other people suggested and used 4 1/2 cups of flower instead of 4, but the dough still came out too sticky. When I braided the dough at let it rise again, it sort of ran together and lost it's shape. When I baked it, the loaves came out a little flat. They taste good, and are moist. I think that perhaps the wetting and covering braids with plastic wrap contributed to the over-softness of the dough. Instead I would suggest rolling out the braid strands with flour to help them keep separated.
Fabulous recipe. Have made it numerous times and it has never failed me. However, I've used regular flour instead of bread flour. It's never been sticky like the other complaints.

I've made this recipe a dozen or more times. If you follow the measurements exactly the dough comes out perfect. If you use more honey, or measure the water in a measuring cup that lets you go over the one cup mark it's easy to get sticky dough. This is easily fixed by turning out on a floured surface a folding a few times. I was raised on challah and this is my favorite - its the only recipe I use now (although I do tend to use 1/2 white 1/2 wheat).
Delightful! I love the touch of honey. I have made quite a few different challah recipes over the years for our Friday night meal, and this one is scrumptious, and so easy to make!
